subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr. Howson) proposed -

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: .- I take the opportunity tonight of replying to the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) in connection with his speech in the House last night in which, to my mind, he launched an unjustified attack on the officials of the Teachers Federation of New South Wales under the privilege of Parliament. It is well known why the honorable member for Mackellar is a member of the Parliament; it is due to the great and powerful influence of his gracious and dignified, scholarly and lovely wife, a woman who wins friends wherever she goes. Otherwise he would not be a member of the Parliament.

speech.para: Last night he bitterly condemned Mr. Sam Lewis, the President of the New South Wales Teachers Federation, a man who has had the respect, affection and love of the overwhelming majority of members of the Federation for many years. The honorable member praised a violent reactionary group which belongs to the Teachers Federation and which is known as the Federation Reform Committee.

The honorable member for Mackellar came into this Parliament 17 years ago. He came in with the great name of Wentworth, the name of his forebears who had done so much in the early history of Australia in bringing it through its days of darkness, despite the errors they may have made. The honorable member has sat on the Government benches for some 17 years - right in the back bench and has lost the confidence of the overwhelming majority of his own Party.

According to the official " Hansard ". the honorable member began his speech last night at 12.18 a.m. and terminated his remarks at 12.27 a.m. He spoke for nine minutes. 1 have made a careful examination of his speech and I find that during those nine minutes he used the word " Communism " or " Communist " 29 times. He used it virtually once every 19 seconds. In recent times in this Parliament great records have been achieved by you, Mr. Speaker, who have held the dignified position of Speaker of the House for a period unparalleled by any other Speaker, and by the former Prime Minister who exceeded all records in holding the position of Prime Minister of Australia. But, Mr. Speaker, the honorable member for Mackellar broke an all time record last night in using the words " Communism " or Communist " once every 19 seconds - 29 times in nine minutes. I think members of the Opposition are fully entitled to regard him as the Mccarthyite of Australia, the violent reactionary of this Parliament and of this nation.

If one scans the book about Senator Joseph McCarthy which is in the Parliamentary Library one will see that he went out of politics in the United States hated and despised because he wrecked the lives of hundreds of decent public servants in the United States Foreign Office and in other branches of the public service. Now let us examine some of the allegations made by the honorable member for Mackellar last night. The honorable member praised a man named Kelly. If time will permit me to do so I shall go into the background of this man Kelly. He is one of the leaders of this violent reactionary group in the Teachers Federation of New South Wales known as the Federation Reform Committee of which the honorable member for Mackellar speaks with so much affection and with which he appears to be so intimate. It is a small group of mostly ultraconservative or reactionary people who seek to impose their will on the New South Wales Teachers Federation.

talk.start.para: - Who is the honorable member quoting?
- It would not be the honorable member. He is such a log no-one would quote him.
- Order! The honorable member will withdraw that remark.

- I withdraw it. This nonpartisan red baiting group has in its leadership people who, as right wing Liberals, seek to enter the State or Federal Parliaments. These include S. T. Kelly who was referred to by the honorable member for Mackellar last night. This Mr. Kelly, while luxuriating in his anti-Communism, has announced he was once a member of the Communist Party and has graduated from that Party through the ranks, unfortunately, of the Labour Party to the Liberal Party. He is now a candidate for the Liberal Party for the electorate of Reid against the present honorable member for Reid (Mr.

speech.para: Uren). He has the Liberal Party endorsement according to my information which I understand is correct.

Another one of this violent reactionary group is H. O. Boyle who stood as selected and endorsed Liberal Party candidate against E. D. Darby for the Manly seat in the New South Wales Legislative Assembly. He recently stood unsuccessfully for selection for the Liberal Party for the Federal seat of Warringah. Another one of this reactionary group with whom the honorable member for Mackellar has such close association is Mr. E. Aavik who is standing for Liberal pre-selection for election to the New South Wales Legislative Council. This gentleman is spokesman of what he calls the " Migrant Teachers' Section, Teachers' Reform Committee ". These are the people praised by the honorable member for Mackellar under the privilege of Parliament. It should be noted that the trade union movement of this country has condemned those who divide wage and salary earners by setting up migrant organisations in connection with the trade union movement.

Another of the leaders of this " reform " group is an American called Evans who became a technical teacher in 1964. I regret he has a Welsh name like James. He did not join the Teachers Federation until 1965 yet he became a scrutineer in December of that year for Mr. S. T. Kelly, candidate in the elections for Federation President, although he had joined the Federation too late in 1965 to have a vote in the elections. Although not a member of the Federation council, he attended council meetings for many months as an observer, taking notes of proceedings. This gentleman also takes photos of teachers who, as private citizens, take part in processions or demonstrations. I believe this man Kelly to be identical with the man the honorable member for Mackellar claimed to be in possession of a statutory declaration to which he referred last night.

A letter has been received for this group at the Teachers Federation office from the Ministry of Information, Immigration and Tourism, Department of External Services, Salisbury, Rhodesia. Accompanying this letter was literature from the Racial Preservation Society including a newspaper, " The British Independent". In this paper appear such headings as "Christian Racialism

Sweeping Britain " and " ls Wilson a Communist? " This refers to the Prime Minister of our mother country, Great Britain. A further publication has a sticker attached with the slogan " Support Rhodesia ".

This is the type of organisation with which the honorable member for Mackellar lines himself up. It is not surprising that some people believe that some members of this Reform Committee have strong racist tendencies and have close connection with the Security Service. The speech of the honorable member for Mackellar should be condemned, lt is a great tragedy that the name of Wentworth should be used to support these groups. To some people Sam Lewis is a great Australian regardless of his political allegiance. No better Australian ever pulled on a boot. He has the overwhelming admiration of all those who have studied his public life and his activities in the Teachers Federation.

talk.start.para: . - May f express my indebtedness to the honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) for having underlined what, of course, we have already known for a long time - the alliance between a certain section of the Labour Party and the Communist Party. He has risen in this Parliament tonight and defended a Communist, a man called Lewis, a liar, a traitor, a man who is prostituting his position in the Teachers Federation-
- Say that outside the House.

- Of. course 1. will say it outside. He is a man who is prostituting his position in the Teachers Federation in order to further the aims of the Communist Party. The honorable member for Hunter is, of course, frightened of the pro-Communists on his own selection committee. I do not regard him as a Communist; I regard him as a coward.
- I object to that remark. The honorable member has called me a coward. lt is insulting and 1 ask that it be withdrawn.
-- Order!
- I do not regard the honorable member for Hunter as a Communist.

- I rise to order. The honorable member for Hunter asked for the withdrawal of the term " coward " as applied to him by the honorable member for Mackellar. 1 did not understand you to ask the honorable member for Mackellar to withdraw.
- Order! In a debate of this type, members tend to be a little extreme in their language. I do not think the reference was unparliamentary.
- I do not regard the honorable member for Hunter as a Communist. I regard him as a man who is frightened-

- I raise a further point of order. I understand your difficulties, Mr. Speaker. It is not easy in all this noise to hear all that is said. I do not think there is anyone in the House who does not appreciate the position that you are in at this time of night with so much noise going on. But a member has called another member a coward. I know that you did not hear it, Mr. Speaker, but the honorable member concerned has not denied using the word. It will set a very bad precedent if that term is ruled to be a parliamentary expression. If an honorable member is allowed to call any other honorable member a coward, the outside public will not think very much of us and we shall have our own selves to blame for that. I think that in the best interests of the Parliament the use of terms like " coward " should not bc permitted.

- 1 am sorry I cannot uphold the point raised by the honorable member. Other phrases have been used in this House which are within the forms of the House and which are very much worse than this word. Unfortunately, some of them have come from some of the colleagues of the honorable member who is raising the point of order.
- Mr. Speaker-
- Order! The honorable member for Hunter will resume his seat. He has been heard and the point of order has been decided.
- He is a cur for calling me a coward.
- With all due respect, I can hardly think that-
- Order! The honorable member cannot canvass the decision of the Chair.
- Mr. Speaker, may I ask a question of you? Did you not compel the withdrawal of the word " log " when it was used by the honorable member for Hunter a while ago?
- I would have been in order if I did.
- I raise another point of order. I have just heard an honorable member - I cannot say which one - call the honorable member for Mackellar a cur. Is that parliamentary?
- Order! The honorable member is out of order.

- 1 thought I was being rather kind to the honorable member for Hunter because, although he has been standing up in this House defending, in the most intemperate language, a Communist and a liar in the person of Mr. Lewis, I have not called him a Communist. I have said that I think his motive in doing this was to get on the right side of his Labour electorate council, which gives him his selection and which, as is well known, has Communist sympathies and extreme left wing tendencies. I believe this was the motive in the mind of the honorable member for Hunter in saying the absurd things he said tonight. In regard to Mr. Lewis, all that I have done is to state that I have in my possession a statutory declaration saying that he was a member of the Communist Party and that he had admitted using his position in the Teachers Federation for Communist purposes. This statutory declaration will be produced to the House tomorrow and I shall ask for leave of the House to lay it on the table so that honorable members can see it. I have quoted it in full, and there is no reason why honorable members should not have it in their possession. The man Lewis is a member of the Communist Party and has been so for many years. He has used his position in the Teachers Federation for Communist purposes. He has manipulated the machinery of the Teachers Federation in order to get Communists elected. I know that the honorable member for Wills (Mr. Bryant) has defended him in this House. So much the worse for the honorable member for Wills. I heard the honorable member for Hunter in this House tonight align the Australian Labour Party with the purposes of the Communist Party, because the purport of his speech tonight was simply to enable Communists to get elected to the Teachers Federation. I heard the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Whitlam) only last Friday try to prevent statements from being made in this House which would help the election of nonCommunists to the Teachers Federation. The honorable member for Werriwa clearly acted in a hypocritical fashion, because he said-
- Order! The honorable member must withdraw the expression "' hypocritical ".
- I withdraw it. The honorable member for Werriwa said that teaching was not an industry, yet he well knows that the teachers are affiliated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions-
- I raise a point of order, Mr. Speaker. This is a contravention of the ruling you gave when you upheld a point of order taken at the time by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
-Order! A question was asked, which was ruled out of order. I hope that the honorable member will not refer to that.
- I refer, not to your ruling, Mr. Speaker, but to the conduct of the honorable member for Werriwa.

- I take a point of order. The only comment I made on this matter was in taking a point of order which you, Sir, upheld. The point of order was that a full generation ago the High Court of Australia ruled that teaching was not an industry and therefore that it was not possible for this Parliament to pass laws concerning conciliation and arbitration as they concerned teachers. Accordingly, it was not possible for any Commonwealth department to be concerned with what are ordinarily called the industrial conditions of teachers. Therefore, the question that was put to the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Bury) could not come within his ministerial responsibility. It was not the concern of the Parliament. I spoke to raise a point of order and you, Mr. Speaker, twice upheld that point of order. I would submit that it is not appropriate and it is not permissible for the honorable member for Mackellar to suggest that I was speaking on this subject in any other sense.

- Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has referred to certain phrases that he used when he took a point of order. Those phrases do not come within the ruling that I gave from the chair when I ruled the question out of order.

- Thank you for that ruling. Mr. Speaker. I was simply referring to the fact that the honorable member for Werriwa had joined in what I would regard as a conspiracy. [Extension of time granted.] 1 thank the House for its indulgence. Mr. Speaker. All I. am saying is that there seems to be almost a conspiracy on the other side of the House. The honorable member for Hunter is involved in it. The honorable member for Wills is involved in it. The honorable member for Werriwa is involved in it. There is a conspiracy to protect the Communists in the New South Wales Teachers Federation.
- I rise to order, Mr. Speaker. ls it correct for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to be described as "the honorable member for Werriwa "?
- Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is recognised in this House as " the Deputy Leader of the Opposition ". 1 direct the attention of the honorable member for Mackellar to this.

- I shall use that description, Sir. We see now that the honorable member for Watson (Mr. Cope) is joining in this concerted effort to waste my lime so that I shall be prevented from saying what I want to say about the New South Wales Teachers Federation. There is no doubt that this man Lewis is a Communist. There is no doubt that the organisers of the Teachers Federation who have been appointed through the manipulations of this man Lewis, like Miss Doris Jobling, for example, are Communists. There is no reasonable doubt about these things. Only recently. Miss Jobling used the car belonging to the Teachers Federation to attend a meeting of the Communist Party of Australia at its headquarters. She, with other organisers of the Teachers Federation, was demonstrating in the streets only a few days ago against President Johnson and was thereby helping to prevent school children from seeing him. I take it now that honorable members opposite think that this was a good thing. Apparently, they approve it. They have aligned themselves with the Communists - with the people who conducted disorderly demonstrations against President Johnson. I am very grateful to the honorable member for Hunter for raising this matter. I am very grateful indeed that he has demonstrated what we on this side of the House know to be true - that there is a section of the Australian Labour Party that is closely identified with the Communist Party and its purposes and with ils research organisation.

speech.para: These facts stand on record now, Sir, I hope that they will affect two elections. I hope that, first, they will affect the election for the Council of the New South Wales Teachers Federation that is taking place at present. The ballot papers are already out and the ballot will close on 4th November. Generally in the past, fewer than half the teachers entitled to vote have exercised their vote. Of the half who exercised their vote last time, only a small majority favoured the Communist Lewis and his cause. This occurred in the face of the fact that the Communist Lewis and his organisation, which consists of the paid officers of the Teachers Federation, had been trying to mobilise votes for those who supported Communist causes. If only we can get the other 50 per cent, of the teachers who do not vote, but who in the overwhelming majority of cases are not Communists, to cast their votes in this election and to send in their ballot papers before 4th November, then the Communists will not be returned in the Teachers Federation in the future as they have been in the past. That is one election.

The other election is one which will be held on 26th November for membership of this House, lt is a matter of regret that the Labour Party has now shown itself to be fully aligned with the Communist Party, and in the trade union movement, in spile of all its protestations against unity tickets and things of that character, is now shown by its actions in this House to be actively supporting the Communist faction seeking election in a trade union ballot. This is a matter of great interest. It should be put on the record.
It has been put on the record by the honorable member for Hunter and perhaps the country-

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's extension of time has expired.

. - Reluctantly 1 speak on the motion for the adjournment of the House. This period has become notorious for name calling, intemperate language and behaviour which quite frequently has tested you, Mr. Speaker, in controlling the House. I do not intend to canvass what has been said. I wish to refer to a human problem, the problem of a constituent of mine who is suffering grievously because of the operation of the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Act 1930-1964. This man's compensation has been reduced from $42.10 a week to $4.30 a week. 1 have written numerous letters to the Treasurer (Mr. McMahon) asking him to do something about this case. The constituent for whom I speak this evening is an honorable man, a good citizen. He was employed by the Commonwealth Department of Works. He was injured and compensation was paid because the Commonwealth accepted the fact that he was injured in the course of his occupation. In the process of time this man sought medical advice and each doctor who examined him declared that he was unfit to continue his employment. Later the matter was referred to the Delegate of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation and on 27th May 1966 a determination was made reducing the compensation, as I have said, from $42.10 a week to $4.30 a week. The letter from the Delegate of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation has this to say -

quote.para: Further consideration has been given to your claim under the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Act 1930-1964. It has been determined that, since 27th September 1965 you have been able to earn, in some suitable employment or business, a weekly amount of $37.80. Having regard to your weekly pay at the date of the injury, as varied, you are therefore entitled to weekly payments of $4.30 compensation from 27th September 1965 until a date to be determined by the Commissioner or his Delegate. A copy of the formal determination is enclosed.

speech.para: This is a heartless determination. It is not in accordance with the truth of the position. The Delegate has decreed that my constituent, an honorable man, is entitled to earn certain sums of money. In a letter addressed to me the Treasurer stated -

quote.para: The Commissioner is satisfied that there are jobs which exist generally in the Lithgow area and which Mr............. is physically able to perform. Available evidence shows that a reasonable wage for the suitable positions is $37.60 per week and it is on this basis that weekly compensation has been calculated. There is no suggestion that the employee is expected to purchase his own business.

speech.para: This despite the fact that in the determination the matter of conducting a business was referred to. In a further letter to me the Treasurer said -

quote.para: You will of course readily appreciate the need for the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation to be guided in his administration of his legislation by principles which have been adopted by the Courts, and in this connection the principle that 1 have quoted above has been adopted by the Australian Courts. In giving its opinion on suitable positions which exist generally in the Lithgow area, the Department of Labour and National Service took into account the physical limitations imposed . . .

speech.para: These are the realities of the situation. My constituent is unable to obtain employment. He has sought employment from the Commonwealth Employment Office. He has attended the Office every week in search of work. The District Officer of the Department of Labour and National Service, in a letter addressed to my constituent and dated 8th July this year, testifies to that effect. My constituent also sought employment at the Small Arms Factory, which is a Commonwealth instrumentality, but he was not successful. He has sought employment with the New South Wales Department of Railways, again without success.I put it to the House that, as my constituent was injured in the course of his work with the Commonwealth and suffered a disability, surely an obligation rests with the Commonwealth to re-engage him and give him an opportunity to earn a living if suitable jobs are declared to be available. He is a family man.

This is a serious matter. My constituent has been subjected to grave hardship. He has been seriously worried about his circumstances. Following the reduction in the rate of compensation an offer was made by the Department to give him a lump sum settlement of $3,200. Rather than try to live on the pittance to which he had been reduced he agreed to accept the lump sum settlement. He took the relevant documents to a bank and borrowed money on the strength of the anticipated lump sum settlement of $3,200. After making those arrangements he received advice that the amount would be reduced to §2,000. This is a grave hardship. It is a scandal and a disgrace. These are not only my views; the Lithgow Press has adverted to this matter in the strongest possible language. 1 speak tonight at this late hour much against my will. I am loath to be associated with the behaviour that we have seen in this chamber in the last few minutes but I want to protest as strongly as I can against the injustice to a good workman who has been injured and whom the Commonwealth refuses to compensate.
The following article appeared in the Lithgow " Mercury " on 10th August under the headline " Daily Pittance Cut to Injured Worker by Commonwealth'" -

quote.para: A 39 year old father of four children who suffered serious spinal injuries while working wilh the Lithgow depot of the Commonwealth Department of Works has had his compensation reduced to below the dole level and has been refused employment by the Department or other Commonwealth Departments or State Departments.

speech.para: This man wants to work, but he cannot find employment in the district. I mention this matter tonight in order to voice a protest against the hardship, the injustice and the cruelty of the decision that has been made.

talk.start.para: . - I do not propose to refer, other than briefly, to the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth). I think it would be more appropriate if there were a couple of doctors in the House-
- Order! I warn the honorable member that he must not make any reflection on the honorable member for Mackellar, in regard to his health. I ask the honorable member to withdraw his remark.

- 1 will withdraw my imputation. The honorable member for Mackellar has chosen to attack the New South Wales Teachers Federation. That is fair enough, I suppose. Apparently there is a Liberal Party ticket in the Federation's elections. There is a strong effort by the Liberal Government in New South Wales to protect itself against justified attacks by the Teachers Federation for lis failure to carry out a policy on which it .vas partly elected at the last State election.

speech.para: There is no doubt that that Government has failed miserably, particularly in the field of education. It undertook to establish a commission and it has failed to do so. Of course, on that commission then: would probably be representatives of the Teachers Federation. The New South Wales Liberal Government, in accordance with the custom of most Liberal governments, would not want anybody with an Independent or properly informed mind on such a body, lt has managed to liquidate the idea of assembly halls in schools. So there have been consistent efforts, by the honorable member for Mackellar in particular, to smear the Federation and to try to reduce its status in the community so that its justifiable criticisms of the New South Wales Government will not be listened to.

talk.start.para: - Mr. Speaker, I raise a point of order. I object to the word " smear ". All I have done is draw attention to the fact that there are Communists active in the Federation. If the honorable member for Wills wants to align himself, once more, with the Communists-
- Order! The honorable member will resume his seat. He is out of order. He has drawn attention to the use of a word which is not unparliamentary.

- rf the word " smear " is too much for the tender conscience of the honorable member for Mackellar, I will withdraw it. I leave the questions of the proper usage of the English language and ordinary decency in our dealings with one another in this chamber to the people who will read the report of this debate. There is no doubt that the Liberal Party is attempting to take over the New South Wales Teachers Federation. I have no doubt that it will fail. I also have no doubt that, even if its candidates happened to be acceptable to the general body of the Federation, the support of them by the honorable member for Mackellar would be the most serious handicap that they would have to bear.

speech.para: The facts are that the New South Wales Teachers Federation has a very democratic structure. It has democratic elections. As far as one can tell, they are conducted with a proper regard for the correct procedures in these matters. It is operating in one of the largest, best informed and most highly qualified public services in Australia, lt operates in close conjunction with large groups of parents of all shades of political opinion. In the 1 1 years that 1 have been in this House, 1 have had a good deal to do with all these groups in my work on the Opposition's education committee. We have never taken any notice of the political texture of people who come to see us. They have been of all shades of politics - from the Liberal Party, the Country Party, the Labour Party and possibly the Communist Party. We have dealt with them as representatives of their organisations. Their politics has not been a matter for our consideration at all. The Teachers Federation has a very good record as an organisation.

That is not the subject on which I wanted to speak tonight. In the last day or so, 1 have received from the Northern Territory a fetter addressed to me in my capacity as Vice President of the Federal Council for Advancement of Aborigines. The letter is written by Aborigines in the Northern Territory. I will not have another opportunity to raise this matter before the House rises, because we will not have another Grievance Day or similar debate. Therefore, I propose to read out the letter, lt relates to land tenure and the strike position in the Northern Territory. 1 will read it to the House without comment. It is -

quote.para: Dear Mr. Bryant,

We, the leaders of the Gurindji people, write to you requesting that you bring before the Parliament of Australia the present position of our people, and our earnest desire to regain tenure of our tribal lands in the Wave Hill-Limbunya area of the Northern Territory, Of which we were forcibly dispossessed in time past, and for which we have received no recompense.

This land belonged to our forefathers from time immemorial, and many of our people have been killed while trying to retain it. Therefore we feel that morally, if not legally, the land is ours and should be returned to us. The very name by which you call us, " Aboriginal ", acknowledges our prior claim to this country in which we are now a depressed minority.

The question of compensation to the present holders of the leasehold arises if this area should be transferred back to us. We feel that the Gurindji people have already made ample compensation over the last fifty years and more, during which time, we and our fathers have been the backbone of the working force which amassed (be Vestey's fortune here, whilst receiving no wages at all for much of the time, and a mere pittance during the last few years. If compensation is being considered it should be made to us as restitution for the manner in which our employers tried to degrade us, by treating us as subhumans.

Nevertheless, Sir, we are not a degraded people and if given our rightful heritage, we would show the rest of Australia and the world, that we are capable of working and planning our own destiny as free citizens, provided that we are receiving an adequate reward for our labours. You may have some doubts about this, as much has been said about the Aboriginal's refusal to accept responsibility; as to this, we ask if you, yourself, would accept responsibility and show initiative whilst working at starvation rates, and in impossible living conditions, on land which had been stolen from you? We think that anyone who would do his best under these circumstances would have to be weak-minded.

If our tribal lands were returned to us we would not want them as another " Aboriginal Reserve ", but as a leasehold which would be run co-operatively as a cattle station by the Gurindji, on which all practical matters would be done by us, except the book-work, for which we would employ white men of good faith, until such time as some of our own people were sufficiently educated to take over from them. We would also accept the fact that if we did not succeed within a reasonable time, the land would revert to the Crown.

These are our wishes which we would ask you to bring before Parliament, and which have been written down for us by our undersigned while friends, as we have had no opportunity to learn to write English.
Yours sincerely,

speech.para: Then follow four names alongside four thumbprints. The names are Vincent Lingiari, Gerry Ngalgardji, Long Johnnie Kitgnaari and Pincher Manguari. I place the letter on record on behalf of the..: people. I hope that, during the parliamentary recess, honorable members will make a close study of conditions in the north. Perhaps in the near future we will all be able to co-operate, at least on this one issue, to bring some simple justice to the Aboriginal people of the north.
Motion (by Mr. Fairbairn) agreed to -

quote.para: That the question be now put.

speech.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 12.44 a.m. (Friday).

debate.para: The following answers to questions upon notice were circulated -

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: What length of time is required to train a national serviceman to the standard necessary before he can be sent on active service?
What length of time was necessary to train a serviceman in the Second World War?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: The training given to a national serviceman before embarking on active service is the same as that given to a regular soldier. The length of time is dependent upon the corps to which he is allotted, and whether he is posted as a member of a unit or as a reinforcement or replacement, but generally ranges from a minimum of six months to a maximum of nine months. In most cases between seven and nine months is considered necessary.
If the soldier is posted as a member of a unit he will have progressed through the following training stages -
Basic recruit; corps; specialist (if applicable); platoon and company training and exercises; battalion training and exercises; tropical warfare training and a formation exercise.

In the case of a soldier posted as a reinforcement or replacement to South Vietnam, the platoon, company, battalion and formation training and exercises are replaced by special theatre and sub-unit training in Australia and further acclimatisation training at the Reinforcement Holding Unit in South Vietnam.

This varied from time to time, but in the latter stages of the war a minimum of six months training was generally accepted. It can be said that, generally speaking, the training given today to a soldier before he is considered ready for active service is longer and more intensive than was the case during the Second World War.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: What provision is made by the Commonwealth Public Service regarding salaries of employees attending Citizen Military Forces camps?
Has he any information regarding the attitude of private employers?
If so, do private employers usually make up differences in pay, do they pay full salaries, or do they expect C.M.F. members to take leave without pay?
Is he able to state the attitude of State public services?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Under the provisions of the Public Service Regulations, officers and employees may be granted leave, as follows, to attend C.M.F. training -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Up to fourteen days, inclusive of Saturdays and Sundays, for annual camp of continuous training; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: Up to sixteen days, inclusive of Saturdays and Sundays, for attendance at a school, class or course of instruction, conducted for training of members of the C.M.F.
This leave is granted on full pay without deduction from recreation or other leave credits, but is available only for attendance at a maximum of one camp and one course of training per year.

item.label: 2 and 3.
item.para: The conditions vary from employer to employer and it is understood that in some instances difference in pay is made up whilst in others members continue in receipt of full pay. On the question of leave, it is possible for a member to take leave without pay to attend camp. A member cannot, however, be compelled to take any annual recreation leave to which he may he entitled during any absence on defence service. In this regard Section 10 of the Defence (Re-establishment) Act 1965 reads "where an employer of a member is required to allow annual or periodical holidays or leave to the member, the employer shall not, except at the request of the member, allow the holidays or leave at times comprised within any period of absence on defence service of the member, but nothing in this section deprives a member of any right to any holidays or leave to which he would otherwise have been entitled ".
The various States have the following provisions -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Queensland.
Government policy is to grant leave, additional to annual leave, and with full pay as follows -

item.label: (i)
item.para: 14 days for annual camp and, as required, an additional 4 days for advance and rear parties.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: in up to 16 days, additional, for schools and courses.

item.label: (b)
item.para: New South Wales.

Government policy is that State employees are granted military leave on full salary for up to 14 days in any twelve months. Where excess leave is required, favorable consideration is given and when granted, pay is made up by the difference between Army pay and Public Service salary.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Victoria.

Government policy is to grant 14 day" leave with full pay in any calendar year. In addition, a further 4 days may be granted on production of a certificate from the Commanding Officer concerned that the additional days are required.

item.label: (d)
item.para: South Australia.
Policy is to grant leave, for annual training camps of a fortnightly duration. Pay is made up to Public Service salary. Leave without pay is granted where Army emoluments exceed Public Service pay.

item.label: (e)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to the statement of a senior Boeing 707 pilot that the recent Queensland air disaster underlined the urgent need for longer runways at major Australian airports?

If so, did the same pilot refer to a recent similar incident where a Pan-American 707 aircraft with one engine on fire had to be diverted to an air force base with 11,500 feet of runway because San Francisco's pavement was too short at 9,500 feet?
Is San Francisco's runway 1,300 feet longer than the proposed extended north south runway at Mascot airport?

In view of these submissions and the strongly expressed views of airline companies, the Federation of Air Pilots and citizens generally, that the present proposed length of the runway at Mascot is unsafe and inadequate, will he give immediate consideration to extending that runway while work is currently in progress, to a length of at least 10,500 feet?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions arc as follows -

item.para: My attention has been drawn to a report in a Sydney newspaper on September 25th 1966. The statement was attributed to an anonymous pilot who made a number of observations, many of which were incorrect. The length of runways available in the Winton area appears to have no bearing on the Queensland accident, and I cannot agree that such an accident in Western Queensland is in any way related to the need for longer runways at major Australian airports.

Without the official investigation report on the San Francisco accident, which has not yet been received, I am not able to comment on the claim made. The choice of airport and particular runway to be used is governed by a number of factors, of which the length of runway may be one. All other factors being equal, it could bc reasonable for a pilot to select the longer of two runways, even though the shorter may have been of sufficient length.
The San Francisco runway is 9,700 feet in length. The presently planned pavement length of the north-south runway at Sydney is 9,100 feet.

The airline companies have not expressed the view that the runway at Sydney Airport is unsafe and inadequate. Despite any views which may have been expressed by other organizations and people, all operations conducted at Sydney Airport fulfil completely all the safety requirements of the International Civil Aviation Organisation, which are accepted by more than 100 countries throughout the world.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice -

item.para: Will be consider bringing down a report each year on the assistance provided, and result achieved by this assistance, in matrimonial issues handled by officially sponsored marriage guidance councils in each of the States?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's questions is as follows -

quote.para: Section 11 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1959- 1965 requires each approved marriage guidance organisation to furnish to the Attorney-General annually an audited financial statement of receipts and expenditure and a report on its marriage guidance activities, including information as to the number of cases dealt with by the organisation during the year. The financial assistance granted by the Commonwealth since the Act came into operation is as follows: -

answer.para: The amount included in the current budget for this financial year is $183,750.

I have from time to time given some thought' to whether I should present an annual report to Parliament on the activities of these organisations and have reached the conclusion that no benefit' would be achieved by my doing so. Statistics are generally misleading and statistics relating to matters such as referrals by courts might give a completely misleading picture of the part that these organisations are playing in this field. The real value of the work done by these organisations can really only be properly ascertained by a followup programme of a representative number of cases, and such a task presents many difficulties. Not the least of these difficulties is the very nature of the confidentiality that must be accorded to persons seeking guidance, and any follow-up could well be regarded as an unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of the individuals concerned.

I believe that' the best way in which publicity can be given to the availability of marriage guidance from approved organisations - which, of course, are all voluntary organisation!! - is for the organisations themselves to inform all sections of the public (with the assistance of other voluntary social welfare organisations and churches) in the locality they serve of the assistance that can be given.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice -

item.para: On what dates, by what means and with what results have communications passed between the Commonwealth and the States concerning legal aid schemes since his speech of 14th October 1965 ("Hansard", page 1893)?
What forms of legal aid are available (a) in Federal Courts, (b) in State Courts exercising Federal jurisdiction and (c) in courts of Territories?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Since 14 October 1965, a great deal of consideration has been given to the question of legal aid. The subject has been discussed at meetings of the Standing Committee of the Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General. I would add that there has been correspondence and discussions between my Department and the Law Council of Australia and some State Law Societies.

In considering what type of a scheme or schemes should be implemented, a number of problems arise. The main difficulty is that the system of legal aid already existing in the States differ quite considerably. In New South Wales, the Public Solicitor gives legal aid: he gives legal aid in most civil matters, but will give legal aid in divorce matters only where there is involved a dispute as to property. However, the New South Wales Government has announced its intention to introduce a comprehensive scheme of legal aid to be administered by the Law Society. In Victoria, the Public Solicitor gives legal aid in most civil matters, including divorce; there is also a comprehensive legal aid scheme administered by the Law Society, which applies a less rigid means test than the Public Solicitor. Queensland has recently introduced a comprehensive scheme administered by the Law Society and financed by interest received from Solicitor's Trust Funds. In the remaining three States there are legal aid schemes administered by the Law Societies. The schemes in these three States and also Victoria are financed from costs recovered and by contributions received from assisted persons. In these four States, the Law Societies receive a State subsidy, in some cases mainly, and in some cases solely, for the purpose of administration of the legal aid scheme,

item.label: (a)
item.para: Federal Courts. The High Court Rules provide that the Court may assign counsel and solicitor to act in any proceedings in the High Court for any person who qualifies under a spec.fied means test.

The Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1909-1965 authorises the Attorney-General to pay the whole or part of the costs and expenses incurred by a person who applied for an inquiry into irregularities in an election within a registered industrial organisation. The authority also extends in some circumstances to an organisation or other persons who have incurred expenses. In addition, the Regulations made under the Act enable a member of an organisation to apply for financial assistance to obtain an order from the Commonwealth Industrial Court disallowing tyrannical or oppressive rules or directing that the rules of an organisation be obesrved

item.label: (b)
item.para: State Courts exercising Federation jurisdiction. Where a person is committed for trial for an offence against the laws of the Commonwealth, a Judge or Justice may give a certificate that the person is without adequate means to provide defence for himself and that it is in the interests of justice to provide it, and the Attorney-General may thereupon cause arrangements to be made fca his defence.
In other cases, the form of legal aid available will depend upon the State in which the matter is heard.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Territories. The Supreme Court Rules in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory provide that the court may assign counsel and solicitor to act in any proceedings in the court for persons who qualify under specified means tests. In both Territories, the Attorney General may make arrangements for the defence of persons committed for trial on indictable offences.

Discussions are being currently held with the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory regarding the introduction of a comprehensive scheme of legal aid in this Territory. In the meantime, legal aid on an ad hoc, ex gratia basis is being granted in proper cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice! -

item.para: What was the marriage dissolution ratio per thousand of the population for 1901, 1933, 1965?
Has there been a sharply rising trend of marriage dissolutions, and has this rise been more marked in recent times?
Is marriage a tremendously valuable institution in our way of life and is it incumbent upon us as a society to provide as much assistance as we can to preserve marriages?

Has his attention been drawn to comments by experts in the field of marriage counselling that the present system of court litigation for domestic issues such as maintenance, separation, child custody, etc., generates an atmosphere of antagonistic, and, too often, unforgiving competitiveness between the spouses so that the seal of irretrievability is most often set on these failing marriages by our legal procedures?
In particular, has his attention been drawn to the criticisms of the present court procedure:, in domestic issues by an official report of the Church of England in Great Britain?

Will he give consideration to seeking a conference with the Attorneys-General of the States to consider the amendment of the Matrimonial Causes Act and Rules, and any other relevant legislation to provide for the establishment of family councils to take the place of courts, and to be staffed by behavioural specialists, including psychologists and marriage guidance experts, which would handle matrimonial causes in private and would provide clinical assistance for erring partners in a constructive effort to save as many marriages as possible?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Not recently. In 1958, the rate of marriage dissolution per thousand of the population was 0.72.
The answer to this rhetorical question is certainly, " Yes ".

[ have read some such comments and 1 am watching carefully the various practical attempts to deal with marital breakdown in other parts of the world. My Department's Marriage Guidance Officer has already looked at various procedures in America and England to ascertain the effectiveness and suitability of these procedures to Australian conditions. I remind the honorable member that the Matrimonial Causes Act 1965 amended the law regarding condonation in order to remove legal obstacles in the way of reconciliation. Where a marital breakdown occurs or is threatened, the primary decision whether to save the marriage or to have it dissolved rests with the marriage partners. The best practical method at present seems to be to increase public awareness of the many facilities for marriage guidance that already exist,
I have seen some Press reports but as yet I have not seen the full text of the report.
I do not think such a conference is desirable.

subdebateinfo.title: Economic- Commission for Australia and the Far East: West Irian.

talk.start.para: m askedthe Minister for External Affairs, upon notice -

quote.para: Was West Irian included in the Terms of Reference of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in 1963 when the Terms of Reference were amendedto include Continental Australia but notthe Territory of Papua and New Guinea?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows -

quote.para: Yes. Beforethe transfer of the Administration of West Irian on 1st May 1963, West Irian came within the scope of E.C.A.F.E. Terms of Reference by virtue of the Netherlands membership of that body. After the transfer, the fact that Indonesia was also a member of E.C.A.F.E. meant that the applicability of E.C.A.F.E. Terms of Reference to West Irian continued.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

quote.para: Will there be an official public inquiry into the Viscount air disaster at Winton, Queensland, on 22nd September 1966?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows -

quote.para: On 27th September I advised the House of my intention to appoint a Board of Accident Inquiry, to inquire into the circumstances of this accident. A Board of Accident Inquiry is a public inquiry.

However, under the provisions of the Air Navigation Regulations relating to the establishment of Boards of Inquiry, the Board cannot commence its proceedings until the technical investigation, as carried out by my Department, has been completed and the report on the investigation has been made available to the Chairman of the Board.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice -

item.para: Does Air Navigation Order, Part 20, Section 20.18, issued on 1 1th March 1966, require that serviceable voice recorders must be fitted to all turbine powered aircraft?
Is he able to say whether voice recorders have played a prominent part in solving many overseas accidents?
Was a serviceable voice recorder installed in Ansett-A.N.A. Viscount 800, VH-RMI, which recently crashed in Queensland?
If not, why not?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Yes.

The United States of America is the only other country known to have current legislation prescribing the carriage of voice recorders. The U.S.A. have not, as yet, published any accident reports indicating the use made of cockpit voice records in the determination of the cause of accidents. However, it is known that cockpit voice records have been examined in relation to a few recent accidents and it must be assumed that the records have potential value.
No.

The original effective date for the carriage of voice recorders in Australian aircraft was 1st January 1963, but, because of difficulties experienced in the development and production of suitable equipment, this date was extended to 1st January 1965. The recorders were carried in aircraft as from the 1st January 1965, but service experience indicated an extremely high failure rate. The failure rale was so high that the equipment could not be consideredto be acceptable and extensive modification was obviously required. A concession against carriage of voice recorders was therefore issued on 5th November 1965, to permit the development and incorporation of suitable modifications. The first modifications did not achieve the extent of improvement anticipated and, therefore, during August 1966, all units were removed from aircraft and returned to the manufacturer, in U.S.A., for further extensive modification. The modified units are now being returned from the U.S.A. and will be placed back in service, as quickly as possible, for service evaluation of the effectiveness of the modification. In the meantime, and pending the achievement of suitable equipment, the concession against carriage has remained in force.
It is significant that very similar problems have been experienced in the U.S.A. and have caused that country to extend their compliance dates for various periods up until 1st December 1966.
